From Sunday's Globe

In Canada, cod remain scarce despite fishing ban

Twenty years after the Newfoundland cod fishery was shut down, the fish have not come back and a way of life is gone. New England scientists and fishermen fear it is an omen.

Comedians' impact on politicians, and other surprising insights from the social sciences.

Nobody knows what the iPad 3 might hold. But what do users want? There are plenty of folks in the tech-friendly Boston area with some ideas.

Stopping age-related muscle loss

Think you have to get weak as you age? Researchers are finding ways to fight back with strategic exercise and protein intake.

The decision to build 20 units of permanent housing for homeless ill people in Jamaica Plain has run into surprising neighborhood opposition.

Advice from a college career expert

Kimberly DelGizzo, director of Boston University's Center for Career Development, talks about ramping up the school's approach to job hunting.

Reaching out through their own pain

Monson residents, still dealing with the effects of a twister last June, are now aiding survivors of the tornadoes that tore through the South and Midwest.

Health & Wellness

Study links exhaust, lung cancer

Diesel exhaust has long been classified as a probable carcinogen, but now there's new evidence that exposure to exhaust from diesel engines increases the risk of lung cancer.
